revision.text:
{{Eastern Christianity}} The '''[[Patriarch of Antioch]]''' is one of the original [[patriarch]]s of [[Early Christianity]], who presided over the [[bishop]]s of Syria, Palestine, Armenia, Georgia, Mesopotamia, and India.<ref>[[Walter Bauer]], ''Greek-English Lexicon of the New Testament and Other Early Christian Literature'', 2ed., 1979</ref>
==Patriarchs of Antioch== #[[Saint Peter|Peter]] the [[Twelve apostles|Apostle]] (ca. 37–ca. 53) #[[Evodius]] (ca. 53–ca. 69) #[[Ignatius of Antioch|Ignatius]] (ca. 70–ca. 107), who was martyred in the reign of [[Trajan]]. His seven epistles are unique sources for the early Church. #[[Herodion of Antioch|Heron]] (107–127) #Cornelius (127–154) #Eros (154–169) #[[Theophilus of Antioch|Theophilus]] (ca. 169–ca. 182) #[[Maximus I of Antioch|Maximus I]] (182–191) #[[Serapion of Antioch|Serapion]] (191–211) #[[Asclepiades of Antioch|Ascelpiades the Confessor]] (211–220) #Philetus (220–231) #Zebinnus (231–237) #[[Saint Babylas|Babylas the Martyr]] (237–ca. 250), who,according to Nicephorus,<ref>de Boor, Carl, ed. (1880). Nicephori Archiepiscopi Constantinopolitani Opuscula Historica. Teubner (Leipzig, repr. NY, Arno Press, 1975) pp.129–132. ISBN 0-405-07177-9.</ref> was martyred in the reign of [[Decius]]. #Fabius (253–256) #[[Demetrius of Antioch|Demetrius]] (ca. 256–uncertain), who was taken captive by the Persians under [[Shapur I|Shapur]] #[[Paul of Samosata]] (260–268) supported by [[Zenobia]], deposed by Emperor [[Aurelian]]; in Paul's time [[Lucian of Antioch]] was head of the Antiochene catechetical school<ref>Suda On Line, Adler number: lambda, 685, retrieved 27 December 2008.</ref> #[[Domnus of Antioch|Domnus I]] (268/9–273/4) supported by Emperor Aurelian #Timaeus (273/4–282) #Cyril I (283–303) #Tyrannus (304–314) #Vitalis (314–320) #Philogonus (320–323) #[[Eustathius of Antioch|Eustathius]] (324–330), formerly Bishop of [[Aleppo|Beroea]], a steadfast opponent of [[Arianism]]; he was disposed in 327 and banished in 329. However, the adherents of the [[Nicene creed]] considered him the rightful bishop until his death. #Paulinus (330, six months), formerly bishop of [[Tyre, Lebanon|Tyre]], [[Arianism|Semi-Arian]] and friend of [[Eusebius of Caesarea]] #Eulalius (331–332) #Euphronius (332–333) #Flacillus or Facellius (333–342), in whose time renovations were made to the great church of Antioch, according to Nicephorus. #[[Stephanus I of Antioch]] (342–344), [[Arianism|Arian]] and opponent of [[Athanasius of Alexandria]], deposed in 344. #Leontius the Eunuch (344–358), [[Arianism|Arian]] #[[Eudoxius of Antioch|Eudoxius]] (358–359), formerly bishop of [[Germanicia]], later (360–370) bishop of [[Constantinople]], [[Arianism|Homoian]] #Annanios (359), immediately deposed #[[Meletius of Antioch|Meletius]] (360—361), Semi-Arian, deposed in the reign of [[Valens]] for [[Homoiousian]] leanings
This deposition resulted in the ''Meletian Schism'', which saw several groups and several claimants to the see of Antioch:
{{Col-begin}} {{Col-4}}
'''The [[Arianism|Homoian]] group'''
* Euzoius (361–378), supported by Emperor [[Valens]] * [[Dorotheus of Antioch]] (378–381)
{{Col-4}}
'''The Meletian group'''
The largest grouping, centred around the deposed bishop Meletius. It moved towards an acceptance of the [[Nicene creed]] and participated in the [[First Council of Constantinople|Council of Constantinople]], but was not recognized by [[Patriarch of Alexandria|Alexandria]] or [[Pope|Rome]]:
*[[Meletius of Antioch|Meletius]] (362–381), who attended the [[First Council of Constantinople]]. *[[Saint Flavian of Antioch|Flavian I]] (381–404), he obtained the recognition of Alexandria and Rome in 399 *[[Porphyrus_of_Antioch|Porphyrus]] (404–412) *[[Alexander_of_Antioch|Alexander]] (412–417), he ended the schism with the Eustathians in 415.
{{Col-4}}
'''The Eustathian group'''
The followers of [[Eustathius of Antioch|Eustathius]], strictly adhering to the [[Nicene creed]], elected the following bishops, who were recognized by bishops of Alexandria and Rome:
*[[Paulinus, Bishop of Antioch|Paulinus]] (362–388) *[[Evagrius of Antioch|Evagrius]] (388–393)
After his death the Eustathians did not elect another bishop. In 399 they lost the recognition of Alexandria and Rome, but remained in schism until 415.
{{Col-4}}
'''The [[Apollinaris of Laodicea|Apollonarist]] group'''
*Vitalis (376–?), formerly a follower of Meletius, consecrated by [[Apollinaris of Laodicea]]
{{Col-end}}
*[[Theodotus of Antioch|Theodotus]] (417–428) (alternately 420–429) *[[John of Antioch|John I]] (428–442), condemned the [[First Council of Ephesus]] in the [[Nestorianism|Nestorian]] controversy *[[Domnus II of Antioch|Domnus II]] (442–449), deposed by the [[Second Council of Ephesus]]. *[[Maximus II of Antioch|Maximus II]] (449–455), appointed by Emperor [[Theodosius II]], accepted the [[Council of Chalcedon]], deposed under unclear circumstances. *Basil of Antioch (456–458), Chalcedonian *Acacius of Antioch (458–461), Chalcedonian *[[Martyrius of Antioch|Martyrius]] (461–469), Chalcedonian, deposed by general [[Zeno (emperor)|Zeno]] *[[Peter the Fuller]] (469/470-471), [[Non-Chalcedonian]], appointed by general [[Zeno (emperor)|Zeno]], deposed by Emperor [[Leo I the Thracian|Leo I]] *[[Julian, Patriarch of Antioch|Julian]] (471–476), Chalcedonian, exiled by Peter the Fuller *[[Peter the Fuller]] (476), Non-Chalcedonian, restored by usurper [[Basiliscus]], exiled by Emperor [[Zeno (emperor)|Zeno]] *John II Codonatus (476–477), Non-Chalcedonian, who held the see only three months and was exiled *Stephanus II (477–479), Chalcedonian *[[Callandion/Calandion]] (479–485), Chalcedonian, opposed the [[Henoticon]], exiled by Zeno, replaced by Peter the Fuller *[[Peter the Fuller]] (485–488), Non-Chalcedonian, restored by Emperor [[Zeno (emperor)|Zeno]] and condemned the same year (485) by a synod at Rome *[[Patriarch Palladius of Antioch|Palladius]] (488–498), Chalcedonian, accepted the [[Henoticon]], *[[Flavian II of Antioch|Flavian II]] (498–512), Chalcedonian, accepted the [[Henoticon]], deposed by Emperor [[Anastasius I (emperor)|Anastasius I]]. *[[Severus of Antioch|Severus]] (512–518), Non-Chalcedonian, appointed by Emperor [[Anastasius I (emperor)|Anatasius I]], deposed by Emperor [[Justin I]]. *Paul the Jew (518–521), Chalcedonian *Euphrasius (521–528), Chalcedonian<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=YP9cuh3KX3wC&pg=PA203&lpg=PA203&dq=Evagrius+of+Antioch+Justin+seventh+year,+tenth+month&source=web&ots=HM1lSQp3Oq&sig=TwNCuYGDd_4YEx0JohZ0VoFASCc&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result#PPA204,M1 [[Evagrius of Antioch]], ''Hist. Eccles.'' 4.5, "he was crushed in an earthquake that destroyed the city in the seventh year, tenth month of the reign of Justin." However, Evagrius' date was wrong. See footnote in reference]</ref> *[[Ephraim of Antioch|Ephrem of Amid]] (528–546), Chalcedonian
The Syriac Non-Chalcedonians recognized Severus as the legitimate Patriarch until his death in 538. In 544, Non-Chalcedonian leader [[Jacob Baradaeus]] consecrated Sergius of Tella as bishop of Antioch, opening the lasting schism between the [[Syriac Orthodox Church|Syrian Orthodox Church]] and the [[Eastern Orthodoxy|Byzantine Orthodox Church]].
==Later patriarchs== For later [[Patriarch of Antioch|Patriarchs of Antioch]], see: * Chalcedonian lines of Patriarchs: **[[List of Greek Orthodox Patriarchs of Antioch]] 518 to present **[[List of Melkite Greek Catholic Patriarchs of Antioch]], covers 1724 to present **[[List of Maronite Patriarchs]] 8th century to present **[[Latin Patriarch of Antioch#List of Latin Patriarchs of Antioch|List of Latin Patriarchs of Antioch]] from 1098 to 1964, when post was abolished *Non-Chalcedonian lines of Patriarchs **[[List of Syriac Patriarchs of Antioch from 512 to 1783]] **[[List of Syriac Orthodox Patriarchs of Antioch]], covers 1783 to present **[[List of Syriac Catholic Patriarchs of Antioch]], covers 1783 to present
==References== {{Reflist}}
